Item_Details.Item_Response: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because of peoples reliance and the belief that everthing posted in the internet is true, as stated in souce four. Also contributing to this is, as shown in sourse three, anyone can post information on Wikepedia.

Misinformation is sometimes posted on Wikipedia and can spread rapidly. In Source #4, a student at Dublin University, Shane Fitzgerald, posted a fake quote in the Wikipedia article of the recently deceased composer, Maurice Jarre. Many different media outlets used the quote in their stories that reached all across the world. Fitzgerald did this to show how false information can be spread and printed a million times and it will eventually be seen as the truth. He proved his point when even The Guardian, a famous British newspaper, ran the quote in their obituary. Professors at Middlebury College in Vermont have noticed that students often cite Wikipedia as a source in their papers. However, the student's in Neil Water's Japanese history class were fed wrong information which led them to get bad results on their exams. The college has now banned the students from citing Wikipedia as a source for information (Source #5).

In source 4, a student from Dublin Univesity posted a phony quoted on a recently deceased author's page. People thought it was from the author,therefore spreading through countries very rapidly. No one even suspected it was fake, except for the administrators of the website. On exams at Middlebury College in a Japanese history class, half a dozen students said that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th century Japan. The only student to discover these falsities was Neil Waters. (source 5)

Misinformation on WIkipedia spreads easily because of how trusted Wikipedia has become and how corrosive information could be quickly trusted without accurate citations. In source #4, A student from Dublin University fabricated a quote "by" composer Maurice Jarre, "A full month went by and nobody noticed the editoral fraud. So Fitzgerald told several media outlets in an e-mail and the corrections began." This information went undetected because of Fitzgerald claimed that "[Media outlets] were under pressure to produce news instantly". So why did this misinformation spread? One idea is that the writers had only glosed over the cite-less quote. The quote itself neatly fit into the thoughts of a composer; that he "'there will be a final waltz his head only he could hear.'" This quote seemed so likely and so real that pressured editors decisively decided to publish it. The quote was shocking enough to attract attention, while still maintaining a guise of truth. So, it was accepted as "truth". In source #2, Wikipedia at one point in time had "[Wikipedia] reached 3 million entires... more than 10 million users contributed to that milestone..." Unfortunately, The shear amount of users both helps and hurts accuracy of the articles on the website. Some articles with questionable material have a banner that states it needs more sources, along with a "citation needed" box after some material that is questionable. However, some of these notices are old, and like in the previous example, can go unnoticed. Information that is more subjective is often the problem; how can we decide if a country is overall in bad shape or how terrible Huricane Katrina is? Also, certain data that requires strenous work, like populations of people in a certain area, can change very quickly without notice. Since certain countries cannot take Census or take it every few years, it makes it that much harder to have good, valid, and up-to-date data that isn't subject to question.

In this day and age, the advancement of technology has created a world where siblings from across the globe are able to contact each other in a matter of seconds via the Internet. In relation to the capability of contacting other individuals from anywhere across the world, the Internet has given society a way to spread news like Southern Californian wild fire. Even a single spark that lasts a few seconds can ignite an enraging flame. Similar to the relationship between a spark and a fire, misinformation on Wikipedia can spread in seconds thanks to modern day technology. However, the ones guilty for this spread of information are the users, not the source itself. For instance, journalists are extremely "eager for a quick, pithy quote" when they are trying to meet their deadlines on articles, as stated in Source 4. In their rush to finish their assignments and publish news before their competitors, journalists overlook the quality of their work. The institution of Wikipedia isn't to blame. The spokesman himself even stated that "if you see that quote on Wikipedia, find it somewhere else too." This spreading of misinformation occurs because of a lack of professional ability from the users.

Misinformation posted on Wikiipedia can spread quickly due to journalists desperately seeking something to add to an article, or maybe something to write about. Source 4 states that it is not that the inaccurate information is corrected, but, "It was journalists eager for a quick, pithy quote that was the problem" (source 4). The journalists got hold of a false quote posted on the Wikipedia page about French composer Maurice Jarre right after his death, even though it was eventually taken down. Once something is made public though, it will spread around the globe quickly, making it too late for editors to stop the misinformation from spreading. When leaked by the first journalists who saw it, they decided to include it in his or her obituary of the composer, but the quote also found it way onto other websites online. Furthermore, when students at Middlebury College, Vermont were cramming for an exam they looked on the internet for answers. The professor figured out that, "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia...and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam" (source 5). The students were a large group and used Wikipedia to study causing the false infromation to be spread quickly among the tudying students students. In both examples, the information was spread quickly due to the fact that people were in a rush to gain knowledge or information that was inaccurate before it could be taken down by those that take out information that is wrong.

False facts from Wikipedia spread quickly because the Internet is global and fast. Journalists will pick up information from Wikipedia and use it, without making corrections to fraud (Source 4). Also, college students are relying on Wikipedia posts for studying. This faulty information is used to prepare for exams or as sources for papers. Although many school, Middlebury College for example, are not allowing students to use Wikipedia, students still rely on it (Source 5).

Due to the newfound celebrity Wikipedia has enjoyed for the past few years, its articles are one of the first links that pop up if one searches for information on a topic online- "Google searches on diverse subjects... like Confucius and concepts like torture give the Wikipedia entry the first listing" (Source #5). This is convenient, but has the potential to become dangerously misinformative. A small experiement was conducted by Shane Fitzgerald to observe just how far a piece of incorrect information could spread when attention was drawn to the subject it concerned (Source #4). The widespread use of the fake quote shows that many have come to see Wikipedia as a definite and trusted source. This is a dangerous conclusion, seeing as a mere student could edit an article viewed by thousands.

Source 4 describes a story of a sociology major who did an experiment by making up a quote, which he claimed came from the famous Oscar-winning actor Maurice Jarre. Though the "1,500 volunteer 'administrators' and the wider public to spot bogus additions did its job, removing the quote three times within minutes or hours" (4), it was not removed "quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pastint it first" (4). Consequently, the misinformation went viral, spreading extremely quickly all over the internet. It was not until Shane Fitzgerald reported to the media that the public realized the quote was phony. In another mishappening, "half a dozen students... asserted that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan" (5). According to Professor Neil Waters, this information was wrong as "the Jesuits were in 'no position to aid a revolution'" (5). In both these cases, it was likely that students and journalists simply believed that the information was accurate because it was posted online. This is similar to Milgram's experiment where people were told to give "learners" shocks for incorrrect answers to questions. The shocks were not actually real, but the participants did not know this. Even when the shocks became dangerously high, almost all the participants followed through simply because an authoritative looking man in a lab coat asked them to do so. The conclusion of this experiment was that people tend to trust authoritative or official-looking figures. In this case, the website Wikipedia looked official, consequently making people believe that it is always accurate.

Misinformation is common on sites like Wikipedia, becuase online users are allowed to edit information, making it hard to keep track of accurate information. The source states that Wikipedia "can be hard to avoid while on the internet", leading to the spread of misinformation.

As the popularity of Wikipedia has grown, so too does the frequency of misinformation coming into the public spectrum, for a variety of reasons. In some cases, researchers or students, trying to get in as much information as possible before in exam, utilize Wikipedia as their quickest available source, spreading the information they learn in study groups and recommending the site to other students who have a similar time crunch (Source 5). In other, more professional cases, media outlets, ??under pressure to produce new instantly??, rely increasingly on Internet sources, especially the most popular of them all, Wikipedia; these news sources, which most consider to be reliable, then go on to spread the incorrect information to the vast public (Source 4). In most cases, Wikipedia misinformation spreads when people are in a time-crunch to uncover the most important facts as quickly as possible, with no time to double check the facts presented to them.

Wikipedia has become so vastly popular that many will use it to find information immediately, as the media did to find quotations for various obituaries for singer Maurice Jarre. "Even though administrators...quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it" (Source 4), it was much too late to stop information-hungry journalists from preying on the Wikipedia article, however inaccurate. The problem is that Wikipedia articles are so widely accessible and available: even with the censoring and cross-checking that keeps the information accurate, it is hard to stop all of the users that get on to an article before such misinformation is removed. The Internet is available everywhere: a million people can read an article before one editor, even if that editor reads this article ten minutes after its conception. And by then it is far too late for the million people that have been misinformed and haven't bothered to check up on their accuracy. Additionally, the sheer number of articles, "13 million...in 271 different languages" (Source 2), prevent any number of editors from truly being able to validate every piece of information included on such a vast online encyclopedia. "Obscure...incorrect information" (Source 5) is not an uncommon thing: it simply goes unnoticed in the gigantic arena of the collection. But when, say, a college history class has a big test they need to cram for, these tiny obscure details spread to a point that proves unacceptable. The problem with Wikipedia is not necessarilly a large quantity of inaccuracies, but the potential effects that those inaccuracies may have.

Wikipedia is a privately run buisness that has an array of editors and publishers constantly revising and editing the site to keep inaccurate information from being added to the site. However, since it can be added to by the general public, the editors are kept busy keeping Wikipedia accurate. A 22 year old student at Dublin University decided to put Wikipedia editors and Newspaper journalists to the test by putting a phony quote of a recently deceased composer on Wikipedia. [1] Even though the Wikipedia editors removed it quickly, within a few hours, the quote showed up in several newspapers all over, including Britian's The Guardian. This happened because the journalists stumbled upon the quote without checking it's accuracy with other sources. Students in a Japanese History class at Middlebury College also took information from Wikipedia without checking other sources while studying for a test. The information they cited was wrong, as their professor was able to correct them. [2] This also happened because the students did not check for other sources to say the same thing. This can happen on any site, but Wikipedia has a notorious reputation for inacurate information. [1] Source #4 Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote by Shawn Pogatchnik from The Seattle Times. [2] Source #5 Wikipedia on an Acedemic Hit List by Noam Cohen from The Taipei Times.

Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread very quickly and it is demonstrated in a few of the articles. In source #4 it talks about a Dublin university student named Shane Fitzgerald that was doing a sociology experiment to see how fast false information on the site Wikipedia could spread. There was a Wikipedia page on the French composer Maurice Jarre. Jarre had died just hours before and Shane saw his chance to do his experiment, so he posted a quote on the page that was supposedly said by the composer but was not. And sure enough within a couple of hours of that quote being on the page, journalists from all over Europe had swooped in and copied it to put in their obituaries on the deceased composer. To Fitzgerald's surprise his experiment had worked profoundly more than he had imagined. The team at Wikipedia that edits the site and checks the reliability of the entries, found the quote and erased it as soon as they found it, but some journalists had already picked up the information. Fitzgerald did release a statement saying that he was the one who posted the quote and was doing it for research purposes. His experiment shows that anything that is put on the internet will be used by people, and that it can spread like wild fire. People that use Wikipedia rarely check the validity of the information that they are receiving and just assume that whoever did post the article was being truthful about it, some people even believe that others can not just edit Wikipedia as they please. This goes to show that whoever does use a site like Wikipedia should check how valid the information that they retained is before they start spreading it to others. Also information on Wikipedia, whether true or false, may spread very quickly do to the number of users that are on the site. In source #1 it shows a graph on the percentage of adults in America that use the internet compared to the percentage of those that use Wikipedia. By 2010 79% of adults in America used the internet, and 42% of them used Wikipedia as a source. With this bulk of people using the site it's no wonder that information on topics can spread so quickly whether it is valid or not. No matter what it is the more people that see it the more likely it is that it is going to be spread, and eventually some people will even start to believe it is true if they have heard it from enough people. Misinformation on Wikipedia does spread extremely fast and those that use the site should double check the information before using it in articles or just retelling it to their friends.

Wikipedia is known to be a website that you should not use because it is not written by experts but only by volunteers. When an Oscar winning composer died, of course Wikipedia was blowing up with views of people who wanted to know who he was and what he had done in his lifetime. So as an experiment Shane Fitzgerald decided to put a false quote on the late composer's Wikipedia page to see how fast it would travel around the world. His plan worked and anyone who saw the page believed that the quote was actually said by the Oscar winner (Source #4). Therefore anyone could put anything on Wikipedia and it could be perceived as true. In another source, it was said that college students were using Wikipedia and they were all getting the same fact wrong on a paper they had to write for class (Source #5). Middlebury College debated on whether they should even allow students to use Wikipedia as a source.

Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread like wildfire. In Ireland, a student posted a seemingly legitimate quote to Wikipedia (Source #4). People used this quote from Wikipedia in the supposed author's obituary all around the world. This shows how quickly false information can spread. In Vermont, students in a Japanese history class stated, on an exam, that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in Japan (Source #5). In fact, the truth was the opposite. After researching this peculiar statement, Neil Waters found that the students got this information from Wikipedia. Waters made huge steps to mark Wikipedia off the "credible source" list, and the students would no longer be able to use it in their papers or on their exams. According to this evidence, Wikipedia can be credible, but in some cases is not and can cause major issues.

In the fourth source we see that any false information on Wikipedia will spread quickly to many people thinking its true. The last source we see how students use the site to much not looking at sources and thinking it to be true, but in fact it was false.

Misinformation can spread quicker then we know these days. With the technology we have, it does not take much time for a piece of information to get onto the web. In,"Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote", A Dublin university student shows how quickly we trust a piece of information put on the web for public display. Shane Fitzgerald found the opportunity when Maurice Jarre passed away. Fitzgerald posted a quote he made up in Wikipedia, but said Jarre had said it. Within hours of this quote being posted, it was taken down by the administrators, however journalists had already seen and used it. After Fitzgerald allowed about a month to go by he decided he should probably tell media outlets about what had happened so they could make the corrections. Another example of misinformation was presented when Neil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College was preparing for an exam. He noticed that about half a dozen students answered a question with the Jesuits supporting the Shimabara Rebellion. When Waters was noticed that the students had researched and found their answer on Wikipedia, he took it to the history department and they agreed that it could not be cited in papers or exams. This information was taken from Source #5.

Wikipedia, in some cases, has been proven somewhat unreliable in the information given out, but it is shocking at how fast the bad information can get out there. One reasoning why this false information might spread so quickly is because of the need for news and information now that happens without double checking sources throughout our society. "The sociology major's made-up quote--wich he added to the Wikipedia page of Maurice Jarre hours after the French composer's death March 28--flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India," said Shawn Pogatchnik in the article "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote," (Pogatchnik.) Another reasoning as to why false information might spread so quickly is just the lazyness of some researchers. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam," said Noam Cohen in his article "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," (Cohen.)

Misinformation can be spread quickly due to the current demand for instant news, as opposed to upholding nearly definitive accuracy. Source #4 highlights this point, using Dublin student Shane Fitzgerald as an example. Fitzgerald's phony Wikipedia quote was spread by dozens of news blogs and Web sites who were desperate to report on the death of the supposed quote's speaker. This massive spreading of misinformation may also have something to do with the level of people who actively use Wikipedia. Source #1 contains evidence that illustrates the fact that 42% of all American adults now use Wikipedia as an information source. With a user base of millions upon millions of people, there is more articles and less ability to fact check.
